questions.title: Understanding Array Access Patterns
questions.description: Learn the difference between direct array access and sequential search operations
questions.review:
Key concepts: 
 1) Storing data in an array means we can jump straight to a position in the array 
 2) Array is limited when we don't know the index of the item we are looking for

steps.comment: When data is stored in an array, the computer actually does not know what is stored in each position. It just knows where the array is stored in memory and some basic information (length, slotsize, etc.) about the array.

However, we can use that information to instantly access any index in an array using a formula: 
baseAddress + (index * elementSize).
Let's say our array starts at memory address 100 and each element takes 2 bytes
To access index 3 we apply the formula: baseAddress + (index * elementSize). And the computer calculates: 100 + (3 * 2) = 106
If we want to access index 5, what value will we get using the formula: 100 + (5 * 2)?
This is why array access is instant - no matter the index, we can calculate its exact memory location instantly
However, if we do not know the specific index of an item, we will have to search through the array one by one
We start with the first index (index 0). It is not 25, so we move to the next index (index 1)
On to next element (index 1). It is still not 25
Onto index 2 and we have found 25! Notice how we had to check elements one by one until we found it

While arrays give us instant access when we know the index, the trade-off becomes clear when we need to find specific values - we must resort to checking elements one by one, making our search time depend on the array's size.
In the worst-case scenario when we want to search for 25 (assuming it is in the array), where would it be?
steps.hint: The worst-case scenario is when we have to check every element in the array to find the target

steps.comment: Exactly! In the worst-case scenario, we would have to check every element in the array to find the target, the only worse case is if the target is not in the array at all

questions.title: Understanding Contiguous Memory in Arrays
questions.description: Learn why arrays require continuous memory and the implications for insertions and deletions
questions.review:
Key concepts: 
 1) Array elements must stay together in memory 
2) Inserting/deleting requires shifting elements 
3) Array size must be declared in advance

code: # First check if array is full
# Shift all elements after index to the right
# Shift all elements after index to the left

steps.comment: Let's understand insertion in a fixed-size array. First, we check if there's space in the array.
Trying to insert 25 at position 1. First step: Check if array is full
Array is full! We return false or throw an error so that we don't overwrite existing data.
Let's try again with a non-full array. Since the array length (3) is less than the maxsize (4), we have space to insert the new value.
But index 1, where we want to insert 25, is already occupied by 20
So we have to shift elements right since we have empty space at the end. We start by copying the rightmost element to the empty space.
After copying 30 to the empty space, we can shift 20 to the next position.
After copying 20, we can now safely add 25 to 20's old position
Finally insert 25 at position 1. And we are done!
Now let's learn about deletion. Starting with this array:
Let's delete the element at position 1 (value 25).
The loop starts with the element we were going to delete, where we take the element next to it and copy it back there
After the first loop, what will the array look like?
steps.hint: We are copying elements from the left to the right

steps.comment: Great! Now we do the same for the rest of the array
Now that we have copied 30 over to index 2, what should we do next?
steps.hint: Look at line 20 of the code

steps.comment: That is right! We clear the last element by setting it to None
Let's try a more complex example: delete_multiple_elements([10, 20, 30, 40, 50, 60], [1, 3, 5]). Here's our starting array:
After we run this line of code, what will the array look like? Place the remaining numbers in their correct positions.
steps.hint: We are deleting elements at indices 1, 3, and 5

steps.comment: Perfect! Now you understand how multiple deletions work in an array. The remaining elements shift left to fill the gaps.

questions.title: Understanding Dynamic Arrays
questions.description: Learn how dynamic arrays automatically resize to accommodate new elements
questions.review:
Key concepts:
 1) Arrays double in size when full 
2) Amortized O(1) insertion time 
3) Memory is allocated in advance 
4) Arrays shrink when mostly empty

code: # Check if array is at capacity
# Copy all elements to new array
# Shrink array if using less than 25% of capacity

steps.comment: In the last level, we learned that array sizes are fixed, but we can use dynamic arrays to make them more flexible and practical. Let's start with a dynamic array of capacity 4, containing 3 elements:
When we try to append 40, first we check if we're at capacity
Since we still have space, we can directly append 40
Now when we try to append 50, the array is full as we already have 4 elements. Time to resize!
We create a new array with double the capacity (8 spaces)
Copy all existing elements to the new array
Finally, we can append 50 to the resized array
Let's look at pop operations. Starting with this array:
Pop removes the last element (30)
Now we're using < 25% of capacity (2/8), so we'll shrink the array to save memory
Let's try to combine our knowledge and go through an example. Starting with an empty array of capacity 4
After all these operations, what do you think will be the final capacity of the array?
steps.hint: We doubled the capacity when we ran out of space, and we halved the capacity when we had less than 25% of the array used

steps.comment: Great, now let's see if you can place the final elements in their correct positions
Great! Now you know how dynamic arrays work!

levels.description: Everything you need to know about linked lists, from single nodes to entire list traversal.

questions.title: Understanding Node Structure
questions.description: Learn how nodes are connected and labeled in data structures
questions.hint: Look at how nodes can be connected to each other with arrows
questions.review:
Key concepts:
1) Nodes are like boxes with 2 compartments, one for the value and one for the address of the next node
 2) We can access the next node by accessing the address stored in the pointer compartment

steps.comment: Let's look at a simple node structure. You can imagin each node has 2 compartments, one for the value and one for the address of the next node. In this case, the first node has the value 1 and the next node has the value 2.
So if we access one node, we can find the one its connected to or (next node) by accessing the address stored in the second compartment and going to there.

Normally, we will only represent the value of the node, not the address of the next node. The next node is the one that is connected to the current node. So the diagram from the last step will look like this:
See if you can decide what this Linked List will look like after we run create_linked_list():
That's it! You've just created a linked list!

questions.title: Understanding Linked List Traversal
questions.description: Learn how linked lists store and access data through node connections
questions.review:
Key concepts: 
 1) Linked lists connect nodes through references/pointers 
 2) We must traverse from the head to access any node 
 3) Direct access is not possible like in arrays

steps.comment: A linked list consists of nodes, where each node contains a value and a reference to the next node. Unlike arrays, the nodes can be stored anywhere in memory.
To access any node in a linked list, we must start at the head node. We cannot jump directly to a specific position.
In memory, linked list nodes can be scattered across different locations. Each node stores both its value and a reference to the next node.
To find a node, we must follow the references (arrows) that jump between scattered memory locations. We can't calculate positions like in an array.

Each linked list node contains a value and a reference to the next node (looks sort of like [value, next] or [5, [10, 15]]). This is how we traverse the list. We go from the head, and then we get the next node from the head, then the next node from the next node, and so on. At the start here, the current node is the head.
We set the current node to the next node. Now, the current node is the next node. We see here, current is not head but now it is node1.
We notice that once we reach the tail, we can't go any further. The tail node doesn't have a next node. So we exit the loop.
Finding a node is very similar to array, we just need to traverse the list until we find the value.
Let's say we're looking for value 25. We first check the head node (64).
Not found at head, move to next node (34)
Found 25! Notice how we had to traverse through previous nodes to reach it
In the worst-case scenario when searching for a value, where would it be in the linked list?
steps.hint: This is like in an array, we need to traverse the entire array to find the value.

steps.comment: Correct! The worst case would be searching for a value at the tail of the list, or a value that doesn't exist in the list at all.
Can you see the difference between linked list and array though? Which data structure would be more efficient if we need to access the 1000th element multiple times? L for linked list, A for array
steps.hint: When we found an element in an array, we know where it is

steps.comment: That is correct! Arrays are more efficient for accessing elements at a specific index, for linked list, we need to traverse the entire list every time we need a value.

questions.title: Understanding Linked List Operations
questions.description: Learn how to insert and delete nodes from a linked list
questions.hint: Remember: When modifying a linked list, you need to carefully update the next pointers to maintain the chain of nodes
questions.review:
Key concepts:
1) Inserting into and deleting from a linked list is efficient, traverse to the right position and just update two pointers
 2) Compared to arrays:
   - Arrays require shifting all elements after insertion/deletion point
   - Linked lists only require updating nearby pointers but you still have to traverse it every time O(n)
   - Linked list operations are O(1) once you find the position

steps.comment: Let's start with a simple linked list
Let's insert 25 after the node containing 20
First, create the new node with value 25
We will have to update the pointer of (20) to point to (25), (30) is sort of floating now without a connection
Point the new node's next to the current node's next (30)
Now we have a completed list with 25 inserted after 20
Now let's try deletion. We'll delete the node after 20 (which is 25)

To delete 25, we update node 20's next pointer to skip over (25) and point to (30) by updating its next pointer to (25).next, (25) is now floating without a connection, effectively removing it from the list
Node 25 is now removed from the list. The final list looks like this, where we can no longer access (25) as it is floating without a connection
Even though we need to traverse the list to make any operation, if we need to constantly update the data, which is the better data structure? (L for linked list, A for array)

levels.description: Learn about binary trees and how they organize data hierarchically.

questions.title: Understanding Binary Tree Structure
questions.description: Learn how to construct a basic binary tree by adding nodes as left and right children
questions.hint: Each node in a binary tree can have up to two children: a left child and a right child.
questions.review: Excellent! You've learned how to create a basic binary tree structure. Remember that each node can have at most two children.

steps.comment: A binary tree's node is quite similar to a linked list's node, but it has two children instead of one. It stores its value, and the address of its left and right children so we can go from one node to another.
Also similar to linked list, we usually simplify our representation of the tree by not showing the addresses of the children but just the values.
A tree starts with a root node, which is the first node in the tree and has no parent. In this case, the root node is 10.
The node (5) is defined as the left of the root or root.left
The node (15) is defined as the right of the root or root.right
In this case, 5 and 15 are also called leaf nodes, as they have no children.
What we are working with here is a binary tree, where each node has at most two children but other than that, the children can be any value and have any order.
Let's try to construct a tree using this function, can you show the result after we run this code?.
steps.hint: You will see that this is very similar to how we traverse a linked list where node.next.next gets us from the first to the third node. Here, node.left gets us from the root to the left child, and node.right gets us from the root to the right child.

steps.comment: Great! See how easy it is after you understand traversal? Let's move on to the next topic.
steps.hint: You will see that this is very similar to how we traverse a linked list, from one node to its children.

questions.title: Inserting and removing nodes from a Binary Search Tree
questions.description: Learn how to insert and remove nodes from a binary search tree while maintaining the ordering property
questions.hint: In a binary search tree, values less than a node go to the left, greater values go to the right.
questions.review: Great job! You've learned how to maintain the binary search tree property when inserting and removing nodes.

code: if node.left is None and node.right is None:

steps.comment: We need to first understand that Binary Search Trees are different from Binary Trees. In a Binary Tree, we can have any value in any node, but in a Binary Search Tree, we have a specific ordering property.
The rule is that, values that are less than its parent go to the left, and values that are greater than its parent go to the right. You will soon see why this is useful.
We can now look at the insert function, let's try to insert the value 7 into the tree. Where do you think it should go?
That is correct, 7 is smaller than 10 so it goes to the left, but its larger than 5 so it goes to its right child. However, the code is not as simple.
We start with calling (insert(7, root)) and so (if node is None) is false, so we move to the next line.
Since its not None, we then check if the value is less than the node.value. 7 < 10 so we call the function again with the left child of the root node, or insert(7, root.left).
When we call insert(7, root.left), we ran insert again but this time root is root.left (5). So we enter the cycle again.
But this time, 7 is not less than 5, so we go to the else statement where we call insert(7, root.left.right). or insert(7, 5.right).
But this time, there is nothing on the right of 5, so node is None and we return a new node with the value 7.
Deleting from the tree is a bit more complex, we need to first understand find_min, which is a helper function that finds the minimum value in a binary tree.
We start with find_min(root).
Because we know that the value on the left will keep getting smaller, the left leaf node will always have the minimum value. Which is the left leaf node in this case?
That is right! We keep going left until node.left is None, which is the case here.
Now let's go to the actual delete function. Let's say we are running delete(5, root).
Most of it is very similar to the insert function, we first check if Node is None, then we compare the values, then we will have 3 different cases.

Case 1: value is less than node.value, which means the target is on the left since it is smaller than the root. We enter the cycle again with the left child of the root node, so delete(value, node.left).

Case 2: value is more than node.value, which means we do the opposite of case 1 as the target is on the right side. We enter the cycle again with the right child of the root node, so delete(value, node.right).
Case 3: value is equal to node.value, which means we have found the target (5). We then need to check if the node has no children, one child, or two children.
Subcase 3.1: If the node has no children (is a leaf), we can simply remove it by returning None.
Subcase 3.2: If the node has only one child (left or right), we can simply replace the target node with its child.
Now the child (7) is at the target's (5) position.
Subcase 3.3: If the node has two children, which one do you think will replace the target
That is right! We need to find the smallest value in the right subtree (using find_min) to replace the deleted node.
We copy the successor's value to the target node, then delete the successor (which will fall into case 1 or 2 as it has at most one child).
Finally, we return the modified node to maintain the tree structure. The BST properties are preserved throughout all cases.

questions.title: Tree Traversal
questions.description: Learn how to traverse a binary tree in-order
questions.hint: In-order traversal visits the left subtree, then the current node, then the right subtree.
questions.review: Excellent! You've learned how to perform an in-order traversal of a binary tree.

steps.comment: Start with a binary tree
Visit the leftmost path first
Process nodes in-order: 2, 4, 6, 8, 12
